David Saff wrote:

>>   That is true, but from other hand you don't really have to _run_
>>tests to see that test cases will be included into suite. Note that I
>>am not talking about completely random suites and in 99.9% suite()
>>method will return the same set od test cases. So, IDE or other test
>>runner could of kept these instances alive or even easier - recreate
>>only this instance using number of the test in the suite as a key.
> 
> I'm not saying that it's impossible to make improvement, but that it's 
> impossible to handle every conceiveable situation, so we need a concrete 
> example of the situation we're trying to address.  See below.

   I am not talking about every situation. Actually there is not that 
much you can do using JUnit3 API.

> I was serious about my question, 
> though--if any of the users on this list are right now frustrated by a 
> test suite that they often use in Eclipse, and can't rerun individual 
> tests in, that's a good starting point for a guess as to the next kind 
> of test suites that Eclipse should handle.  

   Count me as one.

> Please log a bug in Eclipse, 
> and CC the list (I'm currently spending some time on Eclipse/JUnit patches).

   Here is the request I've filled in about 2 years ago which is 
describing this issue from a different angle.

Allow to choose required JUnit test cases
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=40598

   I've also filled number of others requests against Eclipse JUnit 
integration. Please take a look. If others from this list are also 
using Eclipse and like to see some of them implemented it would make
sense to vote for them:

Incremental execution of JUnit tests [JUnit]
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41617
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41651

Run properties for JUnit  does not allow to change test method name
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=40597

JUnit View wasting a lot of screen space
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=35762
   (closed, but I still believe that JUnit view can be redesigned to 
use less screen estate. Since introduction of the progress view this 
JUnit's own progress bar is seem redundant to me but eats a lof of 
screen space).

JUnit do not run all selected tests or packages
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41618

JUnit view slows down the execution of unit tests.
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=49360
   (closed but I still see the slowdown)

[JUnit] A better JUnit and Eclipse integration.
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=49558
   (rather request for research then actual enhancement request, I can 
see some integration opportunities using information collected by 
Mylar project)

Use regular console for JUnit stack trace [JUnit]
   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=72847


>>>One cool thing about JUnit 4 is that while you should be able to do
>>>arbitrary test-creation cleverness using the @RunWith annotation, this
>>>is a static annotation that IDE's can easily check.  So version 17.1 of
>>>some IDE might be able to rerun tests run with TestClassRunner (JUnit 4
>>>default) and OldTestClassRunner (JUnit 3 default), and if it turns 
>>>out a
>>>lot of people are using Parameterized, 17.2 could add support for that.
>>
>>   It seems violating the concept of annotations. You should not
>>annotate the behaviour, but rather define enough metadata that can be
>>used by the tool to decide how to behave. 
> 
> Tricky, maybe, but violating is a strong word.  :)  Can you give an 
> example of how using annotations to identify the Runner that should be 
> used by a particular class might be a problem?  Thanks,

   Let me ask you another question first. Why would you need to have a 
different runner for some specific test?
   This doesn't sound right to me to begin with and may also make more 
difficult to integrate with different tools (including coverage 
metrisc, etc).

   regards,
   Eugene
